div.p:
WHen the Lord firÅ¿t brought me to theÅ¿e poor Indians on the Vinyard, they were mighty zealous and earneÅ¿t in the WorÅ¿hip of FalÅ¿e gods, and Devils; their FalÅ¿e gods were many, both of things in Heaven, Earth, and Sea: And there they had their Men-gods, Women-gods, and Children-gods, their Companies, and FellowÅ¿hips of gods, or Divine Powers, guiding things amongÅ¿t men, beÅ¿ides innumerable more feigned gods belonging to many Creatures, to their Corn, and every Colour of it: The Devil alÅ¿o with his Angels had his Kingdom among them, in them; account him they did, the terror of the Living, the god of the Dead, under whoÅ¿e cruel power and into whoÅ¿e deformed likeneÅ¿s they conceived themÅ¿elves to be tranÅ¿lated when they died; for the Å¿ame word they have for Devil, they uÅ¿e alÅ¿o for a Dead Man, in their Language: by him they were often hurt in their Bodies, diÅ¿tracted in their Minds, wherefore they had many meetings with their Pawwaws (who uÅ¿ually had a hand in their hurt) to pacifie the Devil by their Sacrifice, and get deliverance from their evil; I have Å¿ometimes marvelled to Å¿ee the vehemency of their Spirits, which they acted with no leÅ¿s bodily violence therein. The Pawwaws counted their Imps their PreÅ¿ervers, had them treaÅ¿ured up in their bodies, which they brought forth to hurt their enemies, and heal their friends; who when they had done Å¿ome notable Cure, would Å¿hew the Imp in the palm of his Hand to the Indians, who with much amazement looking on it, Deified them, then at all times Å¿eeking to them for cure in all Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿es, and counÅ¿el in all caÅ¿es: This Diabolical way they were in, giving heed to a multitude of Heathen Traditions of their gods, and many other things, under the obÅ¿ervation whereof, they
with much Å¿lavery were held, and abounding with Å¿ins, having only an obÅ¿cure Notion of a good greater than all, which they call Mannit, but they knew not what he was, and therefore had no way to worÅ¿hip him.

What an entrance I had at firÅ¿t amongÅ¿t theÅ¿e miÅ¿erable Heathen, how called thereunto, and what Å¿ucceÅ¿s God bleÅ¿Å¿ed us with, hath been in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure already publiÅ¿hed, which will I hope through the dew of Gods bleÅ¿Å¿ing from Heaven, have Å¿uch a gracious increaÅ¿e, that the bloÅ¿Å¿oming and budding time Å¿hal at leaÅ¿t be acknowledged, and by many more God bleÅ¿Å¿ed for it, in the growth of the fruit to more maturity; Since it hath pleaÅ¿ed God to Å¿end his Word to theÅ¿e poor captivated men (bondÅ¿laves to Å¿in and Satan) he hath through mercy brought two hundred eighty three Indians (not counting yong children in the number) to renounce their falÅ¿e gods, Devils, and Pawwaws, and publickly in Å¿et meetings, before many witneÅ¿Å¿es, have they diÅ¿claimed the Divinity of their formerly adored multitude, defied their tyrannical DeÅ¿troyer the Devil, and utterly refuÅ¿ed the help of the Pawwaws in any caÅ¿e; neither have they at any time, either by threatnings or flatteries been drawn thereto, although their lives have been in hazard; yea, eight of their Pawwaws have forÅ¿aken their DevilliÅ¿h craft, and profitable trade as they accounted it, for to embrace the Word and Way of God. The Indians which do pray to God, were not compelled thereto by power, neither alÅ¿o could they be allured by gifts, who received nothing for about Å¿even years time, much leÅ¿s that which counterpoyÅ¿e their troubles, and exceed to the drawing of them from the beloved waies of their own WorÅ¿hips: Surely it were great uncharitableneÅ¿s, and derogatory from the glory of God, to think that none of theÅ¿e are truly changed, and that God himÅ¿elf
by his Word and Spirit, hath not in mercy prevailed in their hearts againÅ¿t theÅ¿e evils; nay, may we not hope and be perÅ¿waded by this, and Å¿ome other appearances of God amongÅ¿t them, that Å¿ome of them are truly turned to God from Idols, to Å¿erve the Living and true God? Serve him, through mercy they do in Å¿ome hopeful Reformations, walking inoffenÅ¿ively and diligently in their way, which I hope will more plainly appear when they are in a way more hopeful (by the bleÅ¿Å¿ing of God to their further well-being) which I hope will be in the beÅ¿t time.

I cannot but take notice of this good providence of God by the way, That he hath mercifully preÅ¿erved all the Indians which call upon his Name (from the begining of the Work unto this day) from all extraordinary evil, whereby the Devil and Witches uÅ¿e to torment the Bodies and Minds of Men, not one of them or their children (as I know) or have heard have been touched by them in this kind (only a Pawwaw or two, have not been delivered from his Imps preÅ¿ently after his renouncing of them, but for Å¿ome time have had the Å¿ence of them in his Body with much pain:) The miÅ¿chief that the Pawwaws and Devils uÅ¿ually do to the common Indian this way, is both by outward and bodily hurt, or inward pain, torture, and diÅ¿traction of mind, both which I have Å¿een my Å¿elf: To accompliÅ¿h the firÅ¿t, the Devil doth abuÅ¿e the real body of a Serpent, which comes directly towards the man in the houÅ¿e or in the field, looming or having a Å¿hadow about him like a man, and do Å¿hoot a bone (as they Å¿ay) into the Indians Body, which Å¿ometimes killeth him. An inÅ¿tance whereof I can give, whereby it may the more plainly appear, that it is a great mercy to be delivered therefrom; and it is of a youth, who living with his Parents upon a neck of Land, They
did not pray unto Jehovah, yet their Neighbors who lived there with them, did; This Youth was hurt after the Å¿ame manner, and then preÅ¿ently his Parents pulled down the houÅ¿e they lived in, and fled to an IÅ¿land near by, where I Å¿aw the Indian thus hurt in his Thigh, he was grievouÅ¿ly tormented, and his Kindred about him mourning, not knowing where to find any comfort, or help, for cure could not be had from their gods or Pawwaws: I then took the opportunity to reaÅ¿on with them about their way, with the beÅ¿t wiÅ¿dom God gave me, but all in vain, for they would not hear to Å¿eek the true God, notwithÅ¿tanding he had Å¿hewn his diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure Å¿o apparantly againÅ¿t them for their former refuÅ¿ing of Him, but they Å¿till followed on their wonted Serpentine Machinations: The Pawwaws, and their devilliÅ¿h train, with their horrible outcries, hollow bleatings, painful wreÅ¿tlings, and Å¿miting their own bodies, Å¿ought deliverance, but all in vain, for he died miÅ¿erably.
